photo.description: The magnificent Longwood Mansion located in Natchez, Mississippi was constructed in 1860 by Haller Nutt, a wealthy Louisiana planter. Some say that the home was a gift to his wife Julia. In 1861, with the onslaught of the Civil war construction on the mansion was halted and never finished. Only the basement floor of the magnificent home was complete. Mr. Nutt lived there with his wife Julia ant their 8 children until his death in 1864. Julia continued to live there until her death in 1897. Breaking away from the traditional Greek Revival style of that era, Longwood is the largest octagonal home ever built in the U.S. Following an Oriental revival style of architecture, the home boasts approximately what would have been 30,000 sq. feet of living space. One can only imagine what it would have looked like had it been completed in all of its intended glory. The house still holds many of the original furnishings included Italian marble mantling. The plans called for ample windows and mirrors to be installed in the dome section of the house to be used to capture sunlight and reflect the light through light boxes in the Italian marble floors to the lower floors of the house. In the upper rooms, the brick was inlayed to hold Italian marble statues. The exterior of the house is brick but the original plans were to stucco the brick, which would have given it the look of a fairy-tale castle. Nestled on top of a hill, surrounded by mighty live oaks, cedars and magnolia trees, overlooking small streams with banks, carpeted in ferns, Longwood stands today just like she was left in 1861. Inside the walls of Longwood are still boxes of nails and construction debris along with shipping crates still bearing the name of Julia Nutt. I can only imagine how Longwood would look if she had been completed but even in this state of incompleteness, she is an architectural masterpiece.
photo.tags: longwoodplantation longwood octagonalhome mansion antebellumhome natchezmississippi hallernutt msm62166 nikond70s
photo.title: Longwood-0113

photo.description: Most of the exterior was completed but only the basement interior was finished. Here are some of the tools and equipment the workers left behind when they left the area for what they thought would be a brief civil war. (MG_4424.CR2)
photo.title: Longwood

photo.description: From wikipedia: "Longwood, also known as Nutt's Folly, is an historic antebellum octagonal mansion located at 140 Lower Woodville Road in Natchez, Mississippi, USA. The mansion is on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places, and is a National Historic Landmark.[2][4]Longwood is the largest octagonal house in the United States.. The mansion is known for its octagonal plan, byzantine onion-shaped dome,[7] and the contrast between its ornately finished first floor and the unfinished upper floors.. . Samuel Sloan, a Philadelphia architect, designed the home in 1859 for cotton planter Dr. Haller Nutt.[8] Work was halted in 1861 at the start of the American Civil War. Dr Nutt died of pneumonia in 1864, leaving the work incomplete. Of the thirty-two rooms planned for the house, only nine rooms on the basement floor were completed.. . Haller Nutt's never-finished Natchez home, Longwood, was the last burst of southern opulence before war brought the cotton barons' dominance to an end. Longwood survived decades of neglect and near-abandonment to become one of Natchez' most popular attractions."
photo.tags: natchez mississippi longwood columns fluted capital corinthian
photo.title: Longwood column

Haller Nutt's never-finished Natchez home, Longwood, was the last burst of southern opulence before war brought the cotton barons' dominance to an end. Longwood survived decades of neglect and near-abandonment to become one of Natchez' most popular attractions."

photo.title: Quarters at Longwood

photo.description: On our visit at the Longwood Plantation we get into a heavy summer rain. Luckily there was a side complex with a porch so I was able to snap some images as the rain comes down. The Longwood Plantation is a place that anyone who is visiting the area around Natchez, Mississippi should strive to visit. It is one of the most often visited and photographed places around Natchez, and has even been featured on television specials. View large on black Copyright © Kay Gaensler Photography - Creative Commons Check out my portfolio at www.ensler.de You can also find me on Facebook & Twitter! Please, don't leave awards or fav without a comment (even a small one), thank you !!!
photo.tags: 2010 america amerika gaensler gänsler hdr kay longwoodplantation mississippi natchez roadtrip sommer staaten states summer trip us usa united vacation vereinigte vereinigtestaaten geo:lat=3153722300 geo:lon=9140551067 geotagged wwwenslerde
photo.title: Longwood Plantation

photo.description: The Plantation, also known as Nutt’s Folly, whose construction began in the 1860s, is certainly a unique looking plantation building. Rather than the usual Greek Revival style that was so popular in the South during that era, the builder chose to create a multistory, octagonal, Oriental Revival style. The house is six stories tall and has a large byzantine styled dome. Samuel Sloan, a Philadelphia architect, designed the home in 1859 for cotton planter Dr. Haller Nutt. Work was halted in 1861 at the start of the American Civil War. Dr Nutt died of pneumonia in 1864, leaving the work incomplete. Of the thirty-two rooms planned for the house, only nine rooms on the basement floor were completed. Longwood is the largest octagonal house in the United States. View large on black Copyright © Kay Gaensler Photography - Creative Commons. Please visit my Profile for detailed informations. Check out my portfolio at www.ensler.de You can also find me on Facebook & Twitter! Please, don't leave awards or fav without a comment (even a small one), thank you !!!

photo.description: The magnificent Longwood Mansion located in Natchez, Mississippi was constructed in 1860 by Haller Nutt, a wealthy Louisiana planter. Some say that the home was a gift to his wife Julia. In 1861, with the onslaught of the Civil war construction on the mansion was halted and never finished. Only the basement floor of the magnificent home was complete. Mr. Nutt lived there with his wife Julia ant their 8 children until his death in 1864. Julia continued to live there until her death in 1897. Breaking away from the traditional Greek Revival style of that era, Longwood is the largest octagonal home ever built in the U.S. Following an Oriental revival style of architecture, the home boasts approximately what would have been 30,000 sq. feet of living space. One can only imagine what it would have looked like had it been completed in all of its intended glory. The house still holds many of the original furnishings included Italian marble mantling. The plans called for ample windows and mirrors to be installed in the dome section of the house to be used to capture sunlight and reflect the light through light boxes in the Italian marble floors to the lower floors of the house. In the upper rooms, the brick was inlayed to hold Italian marble statues. The exterior of the house is brick but the original plans were to stucco the brick, which would have given it the look of a fairy-tale castle. Nestled on top of a hill, surrounded by mighty live oaks, cedars and magnolia trees, overlooking small streams with banks, carpeted in ferns, Longwood stands today just like she was left in 1861. Inside the walls of Longwood are still boxes of nails and construction debris along with shipping crates still bearing the name of Julia Nutt. I can only imagine how Longwood would look if she had been completed but even in this state of incompleteness, she is an architectural masterpiece.
photo.tags: longwoodplantation longwood octagonalhome mansion antebellumhome natchezmississippi hallernutt msm62166 nikond70s

I can only imagine how Longwood would look if she had been completed but even in this state of incompleteness, she is an architectural masterpiece.

photo.title: Longwood-0245

photo.description: Longwood Plantation house in Natchez Mississippi. Largest octagonal home in the United States.
photo.title: Longwood's Folly

photo.description: Built by Haller and Julia Nutt, 1860-1861, Longwood is said to be the grandest octagonal house in America. Unlike the other Natchez mansions, which are primarily in the Greek Revival style, Longood is a superb example of mid-19th century Oriental style. Unfortunately, because of the outbreak of the War Between the States, and the untimely death of Mr. Nutt, the house was never finished. However, Julia and her several children finished the spacious basement and lived there for many years. The unfinished nature of Longwood is both a bane and a blessing. The basement rooms contain original furnishings and artwork, while the upstairs provides a glimpse of the intricate details of the construction. It is also a sober reminder of the devastating change of life in the South as a result of the War. Today Longwood is owned by the City of Natchez and is operated by the Pilgrimage Garden Club. The dome atop the house was reconstructed in 1993. The house and grounds, a National Historic Landmark, is open for tours and is a "must see" for those who visit Natchez.
photo.title: Longwood Plantation, Natchez, Mississippi

photo.description: Longwood's original dome spire
photo.title: Longwood spire

photo.description: Longwood Stairs in Natchez 2008
photo.title: Longwood Stairs

photo.description: Back entrance of Longwood. Construction was started in 1860 but stopped when the craftsmen from Philadelphia fled at the start of the Civil War. The trees were planted at the time to provide shade for the kids to play in the back yard. (MG_4396.CR2)
photo.title: Longwood

photo.description: Looking up at the unfinished dome of Longwood. There were skylights planned in the first level floor to allow light from this dome to reach the basement. (MG_4409.CR2)
photo.title: Longwood

photo.description: Column details on the back porch of Longwood. (MG_4412.CR2)
photo.title: Longwood

photo.description: From wikipedia: "Longwood, also known as Nutt's Folly, is an historic antebellum octagonal mansion located at 140 Lower Woodville Road in Natchez, Mississippi, USA. The mansion is on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places, and is a National Historic Landmark.[2][4]Longwood is the largest octagonal house in the United States.. The mansion is known for its octagonal plan, byzantine onion-shaped dome,[7] and the contrast between its ornately finished first floor and the unfinished upper floors.. . Samuel Sloan, a Philadelphia architect, designed the home in 1859 for cotton planter Dr. Haller Nutt.[8] Work was halted in 1861 at the start of the American Civil War. Dr Nutt died of pneumonia in 1864, leaving the work incomplete. Of the thirty-two rooms planned for the house, only nine rooms on the basement floor were completed.. . Haller Nutt's never-finished Natchez home, Longwood, was the last burst of southern opulence before war brought the cotton barons' dominance to an end. Longwood survived decades of neglect and near-abandonment to become one of Natchez' most popular attractions."
photo.title: Grove of oaks at Longwood

photo.description: From wikipedia: "Longwood, also known as Nutt's Folly, is an historic antebellum octagonal mansion located at 140 Lower Woodville Road in Natchez, Mississippi, USA. The mansion is on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places, and is a National Historic Landmark.[2][4]Longwood is the largest octagonal house in the United States.. The mansion is known for its octagonal plan, byzantine onion-shaped dome,[7] and the contrast between its ornately finished first floor and the unfinished upper floors.. . Samuel Sloan, a Philadelphia architect, designed the home in 1859 for cotton planter Dr. Haller Nutt.[8] Work was halted in 1861 at the start of the American Civil War. Dr Nutt died of pneumonia in 1864, leaving the work incomplete. Of the thirty-two rooms planned for the house, only nine rooms on the basement floor were completed.. . Haller Nutt's never-finished Natchez home, Longwood, was the last burst of southern opulence before war brought the cotton barons' dominance to an end. Longwood survived decades of neglect and near-abandonment to become one of Natchez' most popular attractions."
photo.title: Original final at Longwood

photo.description: Built by Haller and Julia Nutt, 1860-1861, Longwood is said to be the grandest octagonal house in America. Unlike the other Natchez mansions, which are primarily in the Greek Revival style, Longood is a superb example of mid-19th century Oriental style. Unfortunately, because of the outbreak of the War Between the States, and the untimely death of Mr. Nutt, the house was never finished. However, Julia and her several children finished the spacious basement and lived there for many years. The unfinished nature of Longwood is both a bane and a blessing. The basement rooms contain original furnishings and artwork, while the upstairs provides a glimpse of the intricate details of the construction. It is also a sober reminder of the devastating change of life in the South as a result of the War. Today Longwood is owned by the City of Natchez and is operated by the Pilgrimage Garden Club. The dome atop the house was reconstructed in 1993. The house and grounds, a National Historic Landmark, is open for tours and is a "must see" for those who visit Natchez.
photo.title: Longwood Plantation, Front View

photo.description: Built by Haller and Julia Nutt, 1860-1861, Longwood is said to be the grandest octagonal house in America. Unlike the other Natchez mansions, which are primarily in the Greek Revival style, Longood is a superb example of mid-19th century Oriental style. Unfortunately, because of the outbreak of the War Between the States, and the untimely death of Mr. Nutt, the house was never finished. However, Julia and her several children finished the spacious basement and lived there for many years. The unfinished nature of Longwood is both a bane and a blessing. The basement rooms contain original furnishings and artwork, while the upstairs provides a glimpse of the intricate details of the construction. It is also a sober reminder of the devastating change of life in the South as a result of the War. Today Longwood is owned by the City of Natchez and is operated by the Pilgrimage Garden Club. The dome atop the house was reconstructed in 1993. The house and grounds, a National Historic Landmark, is open for tours and is a "must see" for those who visit Natchez.

Unfortunately, because of the outbreak of the War Between the States, and the untimely death of Mr. Nutt, the house was never finished. However, Julia and her several children finished the spacious basement and lived there for many years. The unfinished nature of Longwood is both a bane and a blessing. The basement rooms contain original furnishings and artwork, while the upstairs provides a glimpse of the intricate details of the construction. It is also a sober reminder of the devastating change of life in the South as a result of the War. Today Longwood is owned by the City of Natchez and is operated by the Pilgrimage Garden Club. The dome atop the house was reconstructed in 1993. The house and grounds, a National Historic Landmark, is open for tours and is a "must see" for those who visit Natchez.
